item.title: Trump Says U.S. Is ‘In Charge’ of Venezuela, While Rubio Stresses Coercing It
item.description: The secretary of state said that a military “quarantine” on some oil exports would stay in place to put pressure on the country’s acting leadership.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at a news conference with President Trump at Mar-a-Lago, the president’s private estate and club in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday morning.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Calls for Dialogue and ‘Coexistence’ With U.S.
item.description: Acting President Delcy Rodríguez struck a more diplomatic tone than she had on Saturday, inviting the United States to “work together on a cooperative agenda.”
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, now Venezuela’s acting president, in Caracas last year.

item.title: Trump Suggests U.S. Could Take Action Against More Countries
item.description: On Air Force One, President Trump threatened Colombia and its president, described Cuba as “ready to fall” and reasserted his desire to acquire Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Asked on Air Force One on Sunday whether his administration would target Colombia, President Trump replied, “It sounds good to me.”

item.title: Maduro and His Wife to Be Arraigned in Manhattan Federal Court
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s president, and his wife, Cilia Flores, will make their first appearance on Monday in a New York City courthouse, the site of other high-profile proceedings.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: The trials of many notorious defendants have taken place at the courthouse in Lower Manhattan where Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, will be arraigned on Monday.

item.title: In Ukraine, an Arsenal of Killer A.I. Drones Is Being Born in War Against Russia
item.description: As the war grinds on, sophisticated Russian defenses have pushed Ukraine to develop a frightening new weapon: semiautonomous killing machines.
item.dc:creator: C.J. Chivers
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bumblebee attack drones at a combat testing range outside Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Ambassador Kimberly Guilfoyle, the Talk of Athens
item.description: The former fiancée of Donald Trump Jr., and the former wife of Gov. Gavin Newsom, is working hard and pushing deals with American business interests. She’s also up late at parties.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to Greece, Kimberly Guilfoyle, at her official residence in Athens.

item.title: Inside Mamdani’s Decision to Revoke Executive Orders That Backed Israel
item.description: Mr. Mamdani, a staunch critic of Israel and its treatment of Palestinians, knew he would not extend the orders, but he had to decide how and when he would rescind them.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Sally Goldenberg, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: On his first day in office, Mayor Zohran Mamdani revoked every order that former Mayor Eric Adams issued after his indictment in September 2024 on federal corruption charges.

item.title: For Mamdani, a Break With the President Just Three Days Into His New Job
item.description: New York City’s newly elected mayor planned to spend Saturday announcing a pedestrian safety plan. Then President Trump brought a captured foreign leader to his doorstep.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York has promised both to stand up to President Trump and to work with him.

item.title: Mamdani Names Dina Levy as NYC Housing Leader and Pledges ‘Rental Rip-off’ Hearings
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani named a housing commissioner and announced that the city would hold public hearings where frustrated renters could voice their complaints.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Christopher Maag
item.category: Department of Housing Preservation and Development (NYC)
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani appointed Dina Levy, a New York State housing official, to head New York City’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: The Complete Winners List
item.description: “One Battle After Another” won best picture, while the top acting honors went to Timothée Chalamet (“Marty Supreme”) and Jessie Buckley (“Hamnet”).
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Critics Choice
item.media:description: From left, Benicio del Toro, Leonardo DiCaprio, the casting director Cassandra Kulukundis, the director Paul Thomas Anderson and Chase Infiniti, accepting best picture for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: After Christmas Day Strikes, Fear Grips Muslims in Rural Nigeria
item.description: A small town set amid a smattering of baobab trees is grappling with the aftermath of a bombing ordered by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Debris from a missile landed near a round well, center, in Jabo, Nigeria, and burned corn stalks that had been gathered for cattle feed.

item.title: Iran Faces Economic Challenges and Military Threats
item.description: Officials said that leaders were in survival mode amid anti-government protests and the prospect of again coming into the cross hairs of Israel and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Fars News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing protesters in Tehran, Iran’s capital, on Monday. The demonstrations have convulsed Iran for a week.

item.title: Yemeni Forces, Backed by Saudi Arabia, Reclaim Territory From Separatists
item.description: An offensive by Yemeni government-allied forces appeared to turn the tide in a conflict that has become a proxy clash between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Government soldiers manned a checkpoint in the Arabian Sea port city of al-Mukalla, Yemen, on Sunday.

item.title: Vaccines Are Helping Older People More Than We Knew
item.description: Many shots seem to have “off-target” benefits, such as lowering the risk of dementia, studies have found.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: China’s Russian Town Has Log Cabins and Cyrillic Signs, but No Russians
item.description: Enhe was once home to thousands of ethnic Russians. Under Xi Jinping’s push for ethnic unity, little remains beyond nostalgia and props for tourists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié
item.media:description: Buildings with Russian-style decorative features aimed at attracting tourists in Ergun, China, in November.

item.title: Winter Storms Ease Drought in California, for Now
item.description: Experts say that it’s too early to tell what will happen during the rest of the state’s rainy season, but that extreme drought is unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Stephen Lam/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Streets were flooded along the swollen Corte Madera Creek during a king tide in Corte Madera, a town north of San Francisco, on Saturday.

item.title: Behind on Student Loans? Here’s What to Do Now for the New Year
item.description: Millions of borrowers who are behind can expect the government to tighten repayment options this year. Experts say take action now to get help.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: The Venezuela I Know
item.description: Many are celebrating the ouster of a brutal dictator, but the Maduro regime may survive the loss of Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof

item.title: Tom Brady Is Not the GOAT
item.description: That’s not a criticism of Brady. It’s a criticism of how greatness is considered.
item.dc:creator: Chuck Klosterman

item.title: Robert Heide, Daring Playwright and Warhol Collaborator, Dies at 91
item.description: He helped create the Off Off Broadway theater scene, wrote and acted in Andy Warhol’s films, and turned his fascination with collectible Americana into books.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Billy Name Estate, via Dagon James
item.media:description: Mr. Heide in a photo from the 1960s.

item.title: Colleen Keating, CEO of Planet Fitness, on Gen Z and Strength Training
item.description: Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness, wants them to do it in a “judgment-free zone.”
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We used to be a bit more cardio-forward, and now we’re dedicating about half the gym floor to strength and about half the club floor to cardio,” said Colleen Keating, chief executive of Planet Fitness.

item.title: One Week Without Smartphones on a College Campus
item.description: A student-organized “tech fast” at St. John’s College thrust young people headfirst into a world of chalkboard-based communication. (On that note: Has anyone seen Eliza?)
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann and Nina Riggio
